This is a list of European medieval [[marches]].
{{context|date=August 2015}}
==Northeastern marches== At the beginning of his rule as king of [[Germany]], [[Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor|Otto I]] tried to reorganize his realm to prepare an expansion to the East. At the beginning of the year 937, he created two marches: the March of the Billungen, given to [[Hermann Billung]], later [[Duke of Saxony]]; and the Eastern march, given to [[Gero]]. In 961, when Billung became Duke of Saxony, his March was merged with the duchy. In the case of Gero, Otto I, now emperor, decided the division of his territories, greatly expanded since 937.
* [[March of Billung]] (937-961): Carved from the Duchy of Saxony, then merged back. ** 937-961: Hermann Billung * [[Danish March]], German buffer zone against the [[Danes (Germanic tribe)|Danes]] * [[March of Gero]], sometimes called Nordmark or Ostmark (937-965). Carved from the Duchy of Saxony, then divided in five marches. ** 937-965: Gero * [[Northern March|Nordmark]], later known as [[March of Brandenburg]] (from 965): Carved from the March of Gero. ** 965-985: [[Dietrich von Haldensleben]] ** 985-1003: [[Lothar I of Walbeck]] * [[Saxon Eastern March|Ostmark]], sometime confused with Nordmark, or with the Bavarian Ostmark (Austria), later the [[Margraviate of Lusatia]] (from 965). Carved from the March of Gero. ** 965-979: [[Thietmar I]] ** 979-993: [[Hodo I]] ** 993-1015: [[Gero II]] * [[March of Meissen|Meissen]], also called March of Thuringia (from 965). Carved from the March of Gero. ** 965-979: [[Wigbert]] ** 979-985: [[Rikdag]] ** 985-1002: [[Ekkehard I]] * [[March of Merseburg|Merseburg]] (965-982). Carved from the March of Gero, annexed to Meissen. ** 965-982: [[Gunther, Margrave of Merseburg|Günther]] * [[March of Zeitz|Zeitz]] (965-979). Carved from the March of Gero, annexed to Meissen. ** 965-979: [[Wigger I]] * [[Margraviate of Landsberg|Landsberg]] (1261–1347), separated from Lusatia, integrated into Meissen (later Saxony). * [[March of Moravia]] (1182-1918). Created by [[Frederick I, Holy Roman Emperor]].
==Northwestern marches== In 861, [[Charles the Bald]], king of France, created two marches to protect his realm from warriors coming from Brittany and Normandy. Both were named [[March of Neustria]], but will be known as March of Brittany and March of Normandy. In 863, the king created the March of Flanders.
* [[March of Brittany]] (861-987): Annexed to the Kingdom of France. ** 861-866: [[Robert the Strong]] * [[March of Normandy]] (861-987): Annexed to the Kingdom of France. ** 861-865: [[Adalard the Seneschal|Adalhard]], [[Udo of Neustria]] and [[Berengar I of Neustria]] (jointly) * [[County of Flanders|March of Flanders]] (863-877): Downgraded to a County afterwards. ** 863-877: [[Baldwin I, Count of Flanders|Baldwin I]]
Three marches belonging to the Holy Roman Empire were created in the [[Low Countries]]: * [[Margraviate of Antwerp|March of Antwerp]] (974-1190): Became part of the [[Duchy of Brabant]]. * [[Ename|March of Ename]] (974-1033): Captured by [[Baldwin IV, Count of Flanders]] and became [[County of Flanders|Imperial Flanders]]. * [[Valenciennes|March of Valenciennes]] (974-1071): Became part of the [[County of Hainaut]].
==Southeastern marches== * [[March of Austria|Ostmark]], later raised to a duchy; became known as Austria. * [[March of Styria|Styria]], later raised to a duchy. * [[March of Carinthia|Carinthia]] (889-1012), later a duchy. ** ''[[Mark an der Sann]]'', later the [[County of Cilli]], then integrated into Styria. ** ''[[Mark an der Drau]]''; later integrated into Styria. * [[March of Friuli|Friuli]] (776-927) * [[March of Carniola|Carniola]] (927-1071): carved from Friuli, annexed to the Patriarchy of Aquileia. Later formed part of the [[Habsburg monarchy|Habsburg domains]] before being raised to a duchy. ** [[Windic March]], a region of the March of Carniola * [[March of Istria|Istria]] (1062-1209): carved from Carinthia, annexed to the Patriarchate of Aquileia. * [[March of Verona|Verona]] (1061-1250): created by the Emperor as a gift, annexed to Austria. * [[March of Tuscany|Tuscany]] (931-1173): created by the Italian king [[Hugh of Arles]] for his brother, then annexed to the Empire. ** 931-936: [[Boso of Tuscany]] * [[Margravate of Mantua|Mantua]] (1433–1530) * [[March of Ivrea|Ivrea]] (888-1015): created by [[Guy III of Spoleto]]
==Southwestern marches== * [[Marca Hispanica|Spanish March]], also named Gothia and Septimania (806-885): Created to protect Frankish heartland from [[Al-Andalus]] invasions, merged into Aquitaine. ** 806-816: [[Beggo of Paris]] ** 820-825: [[Rampon, Count of Barcelona]] ** 826-832: [[Bernard of Septimania]] ** 832-835: [[Berengar von Toulouse]] ** 835-844: Bernard of Septimania *[[Upper March]] (''al-Tagr al-A'la al-Andalusi''), centered on [[Zaragoza]]: created to protect the [[Caliphate of Córdoba|Emirate of Cordoba]] from Frankish coastal and east-Pyrenees invasions. The northernmost part of the Upper March was called the Distant or Farthest March (''al-Tagr al-Aqsa'') *Middle March (''al-Tagr al-Awsat''), centered on [[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]] and later [[Medinaceli]]: created to protect the Emirate of Cordoba from invasions from the west-Pyrenees and [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]]. *[[Lower March]] (''al-Tagr al-Adna''), centered on [[Mérida, Spain|Mérida]]: created to protect the Emirate of Cordoba from Asturian incursions. *[[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]], named for the fortifications typical of a march: created to protect the Asturian kingdom from Cordoban invasions. It developed into a county, then a kingdom. * [[Margrave of Provence|Provence]] (905-1105): From 975 it became a family title, the eldest bearing it. It disappeared after the death of Raymond IV of Toulouse. ** 905-936: [[Hugh of Italy]] ** 936-948: [[Hugh, Duke of Burgundy]] ** 948-975: [[Conrad of Burgundy]] ** 975-993: [[William I of Provence]] ** 993-1005: [[Rotbold II of Provence]] ** 1005-1014: [[Rotbold III of Provence]] ** 1014-1037: [[William III of Provence]] ** 1037-1051: [[Fulk Bertrand of Provence]] ** 1051-1061: [[Geoffrey I of Provence]] ** 1061-1094: [[William Bertrand of Provence]] ** 1094-1105: [[Raymond IV of Toulouse]] * Aquitaine (885-886): Successor to the Spanish March, became a Duchy. ** [[Bernard Plantapilosa]]
==English marches== * [[Welsh Marches]] * [[Scottish Marches]]
==March as modern-era regional toponym== * [[Altmark|Altmark (Old March)]], region in northern Saxony-Anhalt * [[Altmarkkreis Salzwedel]], district of Saxony-Anhalt * [[Denmark]], a sovereign state * [[Finnmark]], a [[counties of Norway|county of Norway]] *[[Friuli Venezia Giulia]], a [[regions of Italy|region of Italy]] combining the former regions of [[Friuli]] and Venezia Giulia, known in English as the [[Julian March]] * [[Grenzmark Posen-West Prussia]], [[Provinces of Prussia|province of Prussia]] (1922–1938) * [[Hedmark]], a [[counties of Norway|county of Norway]] * [[Kurmark|Kurmark (Electoral March)]], former expression for a region in today's western Brandenburg * [[Lappmarken]], a region and former governorate in northern Sweden * [[Brandenburg|March of Brandenburg]] (colloquial, but not official), [[States of Germany|state of Germany]] * [[Marche]], [[region of Italy]] * [[Mittelmark|Mittelmark (Middle March)]], region in central Brandenburg * [[Pomarkku|Pomarkku (Påmark)]], a municipality of Finland * [[Potsdam-Mittelmark]], district of Brandenburg * [[New March]], former expression for a region in western Poland * [[Telemark]], a [[counties of Norway|county of Norway]] * [[Uckermark]], a region in northeastern Brandenburg and southern [[Vorpommern]] * [[Uckermark (district)]], a district of Brandenburg
==See also== * [[Commandery (China)|Commandery]] (''jùn''), the equivalent Chinese territory
[[Category:Marquesses| ]] [[Category:Europe-related lists]] [[Category:Geography-related lists]] [[Category:Marches (country subdivision)]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Marches}}

{{Infobox company | name = Luchtverkeersleiding Nederland | logo = [[File:Air traffic control netherlands main.jpg |center|250px|Logo]] | type = | foundation = {{Start date|1997}} | location_city = [[Schiphol]] | location_country = [[Netherlands]] | locations = 4 Control Centers (2011) | area_served = Nationwide | industry = [[Air traffic control]] | revenue = {{ubl|[[EUR|€]] 179.4 Million (2012)}}{{nl}}<ref>http://www.lvnl.nl/binaries/content/assets/corporate-publicaties/publicaties-2013/2013.04.26-lvnl-jaarverslag-web.pdf</ref> | owner = [[Kingdom of the Netherlands]] | num_employees = 862 | homepage = [http://www.lvnl.nl Website van de Luchtverkeersleiding Nederland] }}
'''Luchtverkeersleiding Nederland (LVNL)''' is the agency in charge of [[air traffic control]] in the airspace of the [[Netherlands]]. Since 1998 it is an independent [[government agency]]. The LVNL is integrated into the Central European Functional Airspace Block ([[Functional airspace block|FABEC]]).
==History== The origin of the LVNL can be traced back to 1930 when the Royal Aviation Service (Rijksluchtvaartdienst) was created and the Directorate for Aviation Security was created.
==Organisation== The agency is based at Schiphol airport and has offices at 3 other airports: *[[Rotterdam Airport]] *[[Groningen Airport Eelde]] *[[Maastricht Aachen Airport]] In addition to handling civil aviation traffic in the Netherlands, the LVNL is also responsible for the maintenance of all technical installations required to accomplish this, the provision of aviation information, controller training and provision of aviation maps.
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.lvnl.nl Website Luchtverkeersleiding Nederland] (in English)
{{Netherlands-org-stub}} [[Category:Aviation in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Air navigation service providers]]

Default is Bishop --> | metro_archbishop = <!-- Name of the Metropolitan Archbishop of the Ecclesiastical Province --> | coadjutor = | suffragans = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration); use | suffragan = for one --> | auxiliary_bishops = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration) --> | apostolic_admin = | vicar_general = | episcopal_vicar = | archdeacons = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of first collation); use | archdeacon = for one--> | emeritus_bishops = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration) --> <!---- Map ----> | map = Nigeria Nasarawa State map.png | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = The Diocese of Lafia is located in [[Nasarawa State]] which is shown here in red. <!---- Website ----> | website = <!-- [http://example.com example.com] --> | footnotes = }}
The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Lafia''' ({{lang-la|Lafien(sis)}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Lafia]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Abuja|Abuja]] in [[Nigeria]].
==History== * December 5, 2000: Established as Diocese of Lafia from the [[Metropolitan Archdiocese of Jos]] and the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Makurdi|Diocese of Makurdi]]
==Special churches== The [[Cathedral]] is St. William’s Cathedral in Lafia.
==Leadership== * [[Bishop]]s of Lafia (Roman rite) ** Bishop Matthew Ishaya Audu (since December 5, 2000)
==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Nigeria]]
==Sources== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/lafi0.htm GCatholic.org Information] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dlafi.html Catholic Hierarchy]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lafia}} [[Category:Catholic Church in Nigeria]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Nigeria]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 2000]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses and prelatures established in the 20th century]]

{{Infobox Airline |airline = Scibe Airlift |logo = |logo_size = |fleet_size = max. 15 aircraft (in 1987) |destinations = |IATA = ZM |ICAO = SBZ |callsign = SCIBE AIRLIFT |parent = |company_slogan = |founded = 1976 (as SBZ Cargo) |ceased = 1998 |headquarters = [[Kinshasa]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] |key_people = [[Jeannot Bemba Saolona]], President
Jose Numes, Chief Pilot[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1994/1994%20-%200806.html World Airline Directory] ''Flight International'' 23–29 March 1994, page 116[http://www.iss.co.za/Pubs/BOOKS/Angola/15Peleman.pdf The logistics of sanctions busting: the airborne component, Johan Peleman, page 303] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070307005934/http://www.iss.co.za/Pubs/BOOKS/Angola/15Peleman.pdf |date=2007-03-07 }} |bases = [[N'djili Airport]] |secondary_hubs = |focus_cities = |frequent_flyer = |lounge = |alliance = |website = }} '''Scibe Airlift''' was an [[airline]] from [[Zaire]] (today known as [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]), with its base at [[N'Djili Airport]], [[Kinshasa]].{{cite news | title= Directory: World Airlines | work= [[Flight International]] | pages= 58–59 | date= 2007-03-27}} ==History== The airline started activities in November 1976 as '''SBZ Cargo''' with a single [[Vickers Viscount]]. Due to problems concerning the national airline, [[Air Zaire]], Scibe Airlift became the first passenger airline in the country. After covering the whole country, it bought a [[Boeing 707]], which allowed for serving Europe. In the early 1990s Scibe Airlift was at its height, serving a multitude of destinations and leasing its aircraft out to European airlines. In 1992, it operated a [[McDonnell Douglas DC-10|DC-10-30]] on its Kinshasa-[[Brussels]] route. The political instability of the country and the poor financial management of the company brought it to an end. Scibe Airlift ceased its operations on 29 September 1998 when its last aircraft was stored at [[London Southend Airport]].Boeing 707-329C (20200/828) [http://www.skystef.be/B707/OO-SJO.htm] == Accidents and incidents == *On 13 December 1992 a [[Fokker]] [[Fokker F27|F-27-400M]] operated by Scibe Airlift Cargo crashed with 37 fatalities about 10 km (6.3 mls) from [[Goma]] *On 18 January 1994 a [[Learjet 24]]D operated by Scibe Airlift Cargo ran out of fuel and crashed on approach on a repositioning flight from [[Cotonou Airport]] (COO/DBBB), [[Benin]] to [[Kinshasa]]-[[N'djili Airport]] (FIH/FZAA) killing two crew.''[[Flight International]]'', 18–24 January 1994, page 38 *The [[1996 Air Africa crash]] killed an estimated 297, mostly on the ground. It was a lease from Scibe."Le Crash d’un Avian cargo sur un marche au Zaïre fait pres de 250 morts", ''[[Le Monde]]'', 10 January 1996. == Historical fleet == *[[Beechcraft Super King Air 200]] *[[Boeing 707|Boeing 707-320 and 707-320C]] *[[Boeing 727|Boeing 727-100 and 727-100C]] *[[Bombardier Challenger 600|Canadair CL-601-3A]] *[[de Havilland Canada DHC-6|de Havilland Canada DHC-6-300]] *[[Fokker 27|Fokker 27-400M and Fokker 27-500]] *[[Learjet 24|Learjet 24D]] *[[Lockheed L-100|Lockheed L-100-30]] *[[McDonnell Douglas DC-10|McDonnell Douglas DC-10-10 and DC-10-30]] *[[Pilatus PC-6|Pilatus PC-6/B Turbo Porter]] *[[Vickers Viscount|Vickers Viscount 757 and 880C]] ==Further reading== *J Rupert, "Zaïre reportedly selling arms to [[Angola]]n ex-rebels", ''The Washington Post'', 21 March 1997. *[http://zeus.zeit.de/text/1996/05/Chaos_am_Himmel_ueber_Afrika "Chaos am Himmel ueber Afrika", ''Die Zeit'', May 1996. {{de icon}}] *{{cite book |title=Encyclopedia of African airlines |author=Ben R. Guttery |edition=illustrated |year=1998 |page=43 |isbn=978-0-7864-0495-7}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Portal|Aviation}} {{commonscat|position=left|Scibe Airlift of Zaïre}} {{Airlines of the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} {{africa-airline-stub}} {{DRCongo-stub}} [[Category:Defunct airlines of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Companies based in Kinshasa]] [[Category:Airlines established in 1976]] [[Category:Airlines disestablished in 1998]] [[Category:1976 establishments in Zaire]]

{{Orphan|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox park | name = Stepanakert Memorial | photo = File:Victory Monument (37584476052).jpg | photo_width = 300px | photo_caption = The Victory Monument | map = Republic_of_Artsakh | map_size = 225 | type = | location = {{flagicon|Nagorno Karabakh}} [[Stepanakert]], [[Republic of Artsakh]] | coords ={{coord|39|48|41|N|46|45|44|E}} | region = | source = | coords_ref = | area= | created = {{start date|1945}} | operator = {{flag|Soviet Union}} (1945-1990)
{{flag|Republic of Artsakh}} (1991-Present) | visitation_num = | status = All year | awards = | open = | website= }} '''Stepanakert Memorial''' is a memorial located in [[Stepanakert]], the capital of the [[Republic of Artsakh]]. == History == [[File:Artsakh Movement 1988.jpg|thumb|A protest at the memorial on February 20, 1988.]] The memorial complex, built in honor of the 22,000 inhabitants of [[Republic of Artsakh|Artsakh]] who died during [[World War II]], is centered around a 21 meter high [[obelisk]] in the center. Those who died were entombed in the common grave formed on the opposite hill. Another part of the complex is a cascade pool with a fountain and seven ‘weeping’ springs constructed in the style of traditional [[Armenian-controlled territories surrounding Nagorno-Karabakh#Armenian historical monuments|Armenian monuments]] and classic ornamental art. On the granite pedestals are portraits of [[Armenians|Armenian]]- [[Soviet]] soldiers of the [[Red Army]] who were honored as [[Heroes of the Soviet Union]]. The newest part of the complex is a cemetery where the veterans [[Republic of Artsakh|Artsakh]] [[Artsakh War|War]] are buried. From 1945 to 1990, the memorial was managed by the government of the [[Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Oblast]]. From 1991 to the present, it has been owned by the government of the [[Republic of Artsakh]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.armenian-genocide.org/Memorial.18/current_category.203/memorials_detail.html|title=Memorial Complex in Stepanakert, Artsakh|website=www.armenian-genocide.org|access-date=2017-12-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.traveladventures.org/continents/asia/stepanakert-memorial-complex.html|title=Stepanakert Memorial Complex {{!}} Stepanakert {{!}} Travel Story and Pictures from Armenia|last=Kester|first=Boris|website=www.traveladventures.org|language=en|access-date=2017-12-19}} == Gallery == File:Tank memorial Stepanakert.jpg| File:2014 Stepanakert, Monument My i Nasze Góry (02).jpg| File:Stepanakert, Monument to fallen in WWII, 2014.05.11 - panoramio.jpg| File:Հայոց ցեղասպանության հուշարձան (Ստեփանակերտ).JPG| == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Soviet military memorials and cemeteries]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Stepanakert]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in the Republic of Artsakh]] {{Artsakh-struct-stub}}

{{Infobox_TV_channel | name= TV Brasil Internacional | logofile=TV Brasil wordmark.png | logoalt= | logosize= | launch= 24 May 2010{{cite news|url=http://en.mercopress.com/2010/05/24/brazil-launches-its-public-broadcasting-service-targeted-to-africa|title=Brazil launches its public broadcasting service targeted to Africa|date=24 May 2010|work=[[MercoPress]]|accessdate=24 May 2010}} | owner= [[Brazilian Government]] | slogan = | country= Programs produced from:
[[Brazil]]
Operates from:
[[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]] via [[Maputo]], [[Mozambique]] | broadcast area = [[International broadcasting|International]] | language= [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] | key people= Nelson Breve
(president) | former names= | sister names= | web= {{url|http://tvbrasil.ebc.com.br/internacional|TV Brasil Internacional}} | sat serv 1= [[Dish Network]] ([[United States|USA]]) | sat chan 1= Channel 9802 | sat serv 2= Multichoice | sat chan 2= Channel 574 | sat serv 3= Fiber TV | sat chan 3= | cable serv 1 = | cable chan 1 = | iptv serv 1= [[Meo (Portugal)|Meo]] | iptv chan 1= Channel 84 |}} '''TV Brasil Internacional''' is an international [[television station]] based in the city of the [[Rio de Janeiro]] in [[Brazil]] and also via [[Maputo]] in [[Mozambique]]. It broadcasts in the [[Portuguese language]] and was launched on 24 May 2010. Initially it is scheduled to [[broadcast]] to 49 [[Africa]]n nations. There are plans then to roll it out in [[Latin America]], [[North America]] and [[Europe]]. ==Launch== [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]], [[President of Brazil]], launched the television station on 24 May 2010 at a ceremony in [[Itamaraty Palace]] in Brasília where the Foreign Affairs Ministry is based. He portrayed the aim of the project as "presenting Brazil to the world. He called it as "the realisation of a dream [...] I don't want a TV channel to speak well of Lula. I want a channel that speaks well of the country, that can show Brazil as it really is". He also said: "We want a network that talks about politics in quality terms, leaving aside prejudices because this will be a public network showing how Brazilians are beyond our borders".{{cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20100525-brazil-launches-international-tv-network|title=Brazil launches international TV network|date=25 May 2010|publisher=[[France 24]]|accessdate=25 May 2010}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} The [[BBC]]'s Americas editor [[James Read]] said it "shows Brazil's growing interest in Africa".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/latin_america/10152301.stm|title=Brazil launches international TV station for Africa|date=25 May 2010|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=25 May 2010}} [[List of heads of state of Mozambique|President of Mozambique]] [[Armando Guebuza|Armando Emilio Guebuza]] said TV Brasil Internacional would "enrich communication between Brazil and Africa" in his remarks that were recorded prior to the ceremony's occurrence. ==Audience== Among the countries in Africa to avail themselves of TV Brasil Internacional are those that speak the Portuguese language: [[Angola]], [[Cape Verde]], [[Guinea-Bissau]], [[Mozambique]] and [[São Tomé and Príncipe]]. Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has made several visits to the African continent and expressed interest in the promotion of Afro-Brazilian bilateral ties. [[Football in Brazil|Brazilian football]] and [[soap opera]]s are keenly followed by the inhabitants of Portuguese-speaking Africa. The government of Brazil agreed to a deal with Africa's pay TV operator [[MultiChoice]] for signal distribution. TV Brasil Internacional's [[target audience]] also includes around three million Brazilians who are outside Brazil. ==Programming== [[TV Brasil]] broadcasts its programming on TV Brasil Internacional, focusing on news and culture topics. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{Official|http://tvbrasil.ebc.com.br/}} *[http://www.lyngsat-address.com/tt/TV-Brasil-Int.html TV Brasil Internacional at LyngSat Address] {{Television in Brazil}} [[Category:Empresa Brasil de Comunicação]] [[Category:Brazilian television networks]] [[Category:Companies established in 2010]] [[Category:Portuguese-language television stations]] [[Category:TV Brasil]] [[Category:Publicly funded broadcasters]] [[Category:External services (broadcasting)]] [[Category:Media in Brasília]] [[Category:State media]] [[Category:Companies based in Brasília]] [[Category:Companies based in Rio de Janeiro (city)]] [[de:TV Brasil Internacional]]

{{Infobox organization | logo = WFUNA logo pos 2c RGB.jpg | logo_size = | logo_alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | logo_caption = WFUNA logo | image = WFUNA flag new.pdf | caption = [[Flag of WFUNA]] | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | motto = Global Citizens for a stronger United Nations | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = {{Start date and age|df=yes|1946|08|02}} | extinction = <!-- {{End date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | type = <!-- [[Governmental organization|GO]], [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]], [[Intergovernmental organization|IGO]], [[International nongovernmental organization|INGO]], etc --> | status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> | purpose = <!-- focus as e.g. humanitarian, peacekeeping, etc --> | headquarters = New York, USA - Geneva, Switzerland | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using {{Coord}} --> | language = English, French | leader_title = President | leader_name = [[Leonel Fernández Reyna]] {{flagicon|DOM}} | leader_title2 = Secretary-General | leader_name2 = Bonian Golmohammadi {{flagicon|SWE}} | leader_name3 = | leader_title3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = [[Jan Masaryk]], [[Hans Blix]], [[Eleanor Roosevelt]], [[Arthur Ross (philanthropist)|Arthur Ross]] | main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> | parent_organization = <!-- if one --> | affiliations = | budget = | remarks = "WFUNA connects the United Nations to the people—and now, more than ever before, engaged global citizens shape history." Ban Ki Moon, Former Secretary-General, United Nations, April 2016 | name = World Federation of United Nations Associations | former name = | image_border = | size = <!-- default 200px --> | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = | map2 = | merger = | location = | region_served = | membership = | general = <!-- Secretary General --> | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{url|wfuna.org}} | map = {{Location map+|World#Europe#North America | caption = Offices of the WFUNA Secretariat##Offices of the WFUNA Secretariat in Europe##Offices of the WFUNA Secretariat in north America | width = 240 | float = center | border = none | places = {{Location map~ | World#Europe#North America | label = New York | label_size = 0 | outside = 1 | link = New York City | alt = New York | lat_deg = 40.7504266 | lon_deg = -73.9713254 }} {{Location map~ | World#Europe#North America | label = Geneva | label_size = 0 | outside = 1 | link = Geneva | alt = Geneva | lat_deg = 46.226598 | lon_deg = 6.140363 }} {{Location map~ | World#Europe#North America | label = Brussels | label_size = 0 | outside = 1 | link = Brussels | alt = Brussels | lat_deg = 50.8503396 | lon_deg = 4.3517103 }} {{Location map~ | World#Europe#North America | label = Seoul | label_size = 0 | outside = 1 | link = Seoul | alt = Seoul | lat_deg = 37.566536 | lon_deg = 126.977966 }} }} | parent = | formerly = | footnotes = | sec_gen = | abbreviation = WFUNA, {{lang|fr|FMANU}} }} The '''World Federation of United Nations Associations''' ('''WFUNA''') (French: ''Fédération Mondiale des Associations pour les Nations Unies - '''FMANU''''') was founded in 1946 as a Federation of national associations. Its obectives are to promote the values of the [[UN Charter]], defend [[multilateralism]], work towards a better United Nations Organisation and raise awarness on the main pillars of work of the [[United Nations]] - peace and security, sustainable development, and human rights.
WFUNA is a [[non-governmental organization]] with Consultative Status at the [[United Nations Economic and Social Council]] (ECOSOC) and consultative or liaison links with many other UN organizations and agencies. As a Federation, its membership is made of 95 [[United Nations Associations]] (UNAs) in as many member states of the UN.
WFUNA is the largest non-profit organization with the mission of supporting the principles and purposes of the UN.
__TOC__
== History == WFUNA was founded in [[Grand Duchy of Luxembourg|Luxembourg]] on 2 August 1946 by 22 national [[United Nations Association|United Nations Associations]] (UNAs). The Constitution they adopted proclaims that:
{{quote|"We the representatives of the United Nations Associations in our respective countries,
Believing that since wars begin in the minds of men, it is in the minds of men that the defenses of peace must be constructed, and
Believing that the peace must be founded, if it is not to fail, upon the intellectual and moral solidarity of all peoples,
Have resolved to combine our efforts to form an association of the peoples to be known as the World Federation of United Nations Associations."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wfuna.org/sites/default/files/wysiwyg/images/wfuna40pa_2012constitution.pdf|title=Constitution of WFUNA (pdf format)|publisher=World Federation of United Nations Associations|accessdate=9 September 2013}}</ref>}}
Over the years, UNAs have been established in more UN member-States especially as new countries were formed and joined the UN.
The [[UN General Assembly]] has adopted resolutions expressing appreciation for the Federations efforts to promote wider public support for the UN. In 1986 resolution 41/68 concerning questions relating to information dedicated an entire section to commending the efforts of WFUNA and UNAs around the world for their "mobilization of popular support for the programs and work of the United Nations".
[[Eleanor Roosevelt]] was an active participant in WFUNA.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wfuna.org/history|title=History {{!}} World Federation of United Nations Associations {{!}} WFUNA|website=www.wfuna.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref>.
In practical terms, WFUNA played a crucial role by helping people in those countries where human rights were violated, such as Franco’s Spain, some of the former communist countries in [[Eastern Europe]] and in the [[Middle East]]. WFUNA brought together people of divided countries – such as East and West Germany and [[Cyprus]], and the opponents in conflicts, for example between Israel and [[Egypt]] in the late 1960s.
WFUNA helped promote "[[Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe|Security and Co-operation in Europe]]" (CSCE) by holding in 1967 the first conference on this topic. Other NGOs followed WFUNA’s campaign which continued until 1975 when the Final Act was signed at [[Helsinki]] by 35 governments, including United States and Canada, establishing the CSCE process. Further campaigning led in 1994 to the CSCE process that consisted of a Biennial Review Conference being raised to a Permanent Organization (OSCE).
[[File:WFUNA70.jpg|thumb|Visual identity celebrating the 70 years of the Organisation (1946-2016)]]
WFUNA, including its African UNA members, made significant contributions to the NGO campaign for the abolition of [[Apartheid]]. The 32nd General Assembly of the UN, in 1977, received a resolution from the 117th WFUNA Executive Committee meeting, which requested:
"The [[Security Council]] of the UN to give urgent consideration to the taking of immediate steps to ensure that no State, multinational or other body or person be allowed to provide [[South Africa]] or [[Rhodesia]] with any equipment, technology or production of [[nuclear weapons]] of any kind".
WFUNA facilitated high-level informal consultations on disarmament issues between key experts of the USA and [[USSR]] during the [[Cold War]]. It organized a number of NGO Seminars on [[disarmament]] in cooperation with the UN, [[UNESCO]] and other NGOs.
During its history, WFUNA has served as a forum for global dialogues on development. Several suggestions, like the establishment of an [[Economic Commission for Africa]], were first adopted at the WFUNA Plenary Assemblies and then endorsed by governments.
WFUNA has actively supported reform of the UN and its capacity to meet new tasks and challenges. WFUNA has continually received recognition from the highest ranks of the UN. The sentiments in this statement by UN [[Secretary-General]], [[Dag Hammerskjöld]], to WFUNA's 12th Plenary Assembly were shared by his successors: "I wish... to express my appreciation of your most essential service. At the same time, I wish to urge you to fresh endeavors. Over the years you have accomplished much and have acted with an ever increasing sense of your great responsibilities."
For many years WFUNA conducted a fund raising program based on the sale of first day covers of UN stamps and lithographs produced by artists and celebrities, such as [[Picasso]], Lou Zheng Jang, [[Joan Miró|Miró]], [[Salvador Dalí]], Ruben Leyva, [[Al Hirschfeld]] and [[Andy Warhol]] to promote the ideals of the UN. This highly successful program ran for several decades during the 20th century.
==Leadership== [[File:President Fernandez on Election Day.jpg|thumb|[[Leonel Fernandez]] and WFUNA's Leadership on the day of his election, 20 October 2018]]
{| class="sortable wikitable" !Nr !Director !Country !Term
|- | || [[Leonel Fernandez]] || {{DOM}}|| 20 November 2018 – present |- | || [[Park Soo-gil]] || {{KOR}}|| 11 August 2009 – 20 November 2018 |- | || [[Hans Blix]] || {{SWE}}|| 2006 – 11 August 2009 |-
|}
== Membership == {{see also|List of United Nations Associations}} There are currently 95 UN Associations connecting hundreds of thousands of people to the United Nations. UNAs at the national level mainly play a role in:
[[File:CountrieswithUNAssociations.svg|thumb|UN member-States with a United Nations Association]]
* Disseminating information and educational materials about the UN * Lobbying the government, political parties and interest groups in support of the UN * Conducting Model UN conferences * Stimulating the media to provide frequent and accurate coverage of the UN and its programs
== Areas of Work == WFUNA is involved with the UN system since its inception and has been working with most Member States through its activities and through its member Associations. *Transparency at the UN: as part of WFUNA's mandate to strengthen and improve the UN, the organization implements initiatives that increase the transparency of established UN processes.
*Civil Society Working Towards the [[Sustainable Development Goals]]: as part of a belief that people's involvement in local, national, and global decision-making is essential to achieving the UN's goals, WFUNA ensures that civil society is involved in UN programs and events.
*[[Global citizenship education|Global Citizenship]] Around the World: as global citizenship is at the heart of WFUNA's mission, the organization facilitates regular programs that foster critical-thinking and problem-solving, and empowers people to act in their communities.
*Human Rights: since the adoption in 1948 of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]], WFUNA considered human rights advocacy as a central part of its programs. A number of international seminars in different regions of the world have been organized by WFUNA on the teaching of human rights. The proposal for creating the position of a [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]] was on WFUNA’s agenda for many years.
==See also== *[[Otto Hahn Peace Medal]]
